Award.AwardTitle: Laser spectroscopy of metal and semimetal molecules
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this renewal award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanism Program A (CSDM-A) of the Division of Chemistry supports Professor Michael D. Morse of the University of Utah in a project that will use lasers to probe the structural and bonding properties of small metal and boron containing molecules in the gas phase. These investigations will provide data that will be used as benchmarks for results obtained by modern computational techniques. This project will increase fundamental knowledge of the nature of the chemical bonds in a series of interesting and important molecules. Students participating in this research will receive training in instrument development, vacuum technology, electronics and computational techniques. The principal investigator will conduct a series of workshops for high school teachers of advanced placement chemistry.

This project will use laser spectroscopy to develop a fundamental understanding of the electronic structure and chemical bonding in small molecules. Systems to be studied include: (1) the molecules BNB and BC2, triatomic molecules for which high-level theory yields conflicting results; (2) boron clusters,which have been shown to have interesting electronic structure, which influences the molecular structure; (3) diatomic metal and silicon containing species, to determine the bond lengths and electronic symmetries of these species; and (4) a range of 3d, 4d, 5d, and 4f metal molecules with a cryo-cooled ion trap, in order to build up an accurate (<0.3 kJ/mol) database of bond dissociation energies for metal-metal bonds. Extensive collaborations with computational and theoretical specialists are planned.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Grant CHE-1362152 has funded research on small metal- and semi-metal containing molecules in the Morse group, with the goal of obtaining fundamental information concerning the chemical bonding, electronic structure, and bond dissociation energies in these species.

One project that was undertaken was to measure the spectra of diatomic CrW, in order to investigate multiple bonding in the Group 6 transition metal diatomics.  These species are in principle capable of forming a sextuple bond, with the s-orbitals and all five d-orbitals on the two metal centers combining to form 6 bonding molecular orbitals, each holding two electrons.  We measured the CrW bond length, finding it to be 1.881 Å.  This compares to inter-atomic spacing in solid Cr and W of 2.52 and 2.74 Å, respectively, showing that the diatomic CrW molecule exhibits high-order multiple bonding.  In addition, we were able to measure the bond dissociation energy of the CrW molecule for the first time, obtaining the value 2.867(1) eV.  This is quite close to the geometric mean of the Cr2 and W2 molecules, 2.83 eV.

The bond dissociation energy of CrW was determined by scanning the spectrum of the molecule, and locating a threshold where the excited state lifetime abruptly dropped.  Below this energy, the excited molecules could only lose energy by fluorescence, a process that exhibits a lifetime of about 1 microsecond.  Above a sharply defined threshold, however, the lifetime dropped to roughly 30 nanoseconds, indicating that a new decay process was occurring.  This threshold is very well defined (it occurs at 23,127 ± 10 cm-1) and corresponds to the bond dissociation energy of the molecule.  The new decay process that sets in above this energy is dissociation.

Following up on this study, we have recognized that the high density of electronic states that exist in small gas-phase transition metal molecules means that it should be possible to use this same method to measure bond dissociation energies in more chemically interesting and relevant species, such as MC, MSi, MS molecules, etc.  Therefore, we have embarked on a program to measure these species.  This work has been more successful than I ever imagined!  During the time frame of this grant, we have measured and published bond dissociation energies of 21 diatomic transition metal carbides, silicides, nitrides, sulfides, and selenides.  These data are of high precision because the dissociation process sets in quite rapidly when the bond dissociation energy is exceeded.  As a result, we have been able to report bond dissociation energies with error limits that are below 0.5%, and are often below 0.1% of the measured value.

The molecules whose bond energies we have measured during this grant, and their bond energy values (in eV, with error limits, in units of the last reported digit, provided in parentheses) are:

 TiSi 2.201(3)        TiSe  3.998(6)       VC   4.109(3)        NiC  4.167(3)       ZrSi  2.950(3)       ZrSe  4.902(3)       VN   4.997(2)       NiS  3.651(3)       HfSi  2.871(3)       HfSe  5.154(4)       VS   4.535(3)       NiSe  3.218(3)              VSi  2.234(3)        VSe  3.884(3)       FeC  3.961(19)    CrW  2.8671(1)     NbSi 3.080(3)       NbSe 4.834(3)      FeS  3.240(3)                                     TaSi  2.999(3)       TaSe  4.705(3)      FeSe 2.739(6)

We are in the process of literally writing the book regarding the bond strengths of neutral transition metal elements bonded to main group elements.  In addition to providing crucial points of calibration for the development of improved computational methods, by studying these bond energies across the entire transition metal series, we are developing a fundamental understanding of the broader trends that govern chemical bonding in transition metal species.  The results will have broad impact across a wide variety of chemical applications, particularly in catalysis, organometallic chemistry, and the development of improved computational methods.
